page.title: 07East Hagbourne Buildings
page.content: Few houses in the village date before 1600 as a fire destroyed the village in 1628. The older homes have oak and elm timber beams with infill of brick and mortar. Some of the houses have thatched rooves whilst some about 150yrs old have hand made clay tiles. Iron and lead pipes take water. The oldest houses are in Church Close and Shoe Lane some of these being converted barns. Near the Croft there is a 300yr old house that was originally only 6ft tall made with mud. This was later extended by lathe and plaster into a two storey building and about 70-100yrs ago was again extended with red brick. The house is curently being gutted and there is little evidence of the original building material. Houses built this century are mainly brick with tiled rooves, plastic gutters and downpipes and lack chimneys after 1950.
